swipes.primaryText:

But the challenge?

Getting your emails out of Gmail’s Promotions tab (or worse - Spam) is... HARD!

And if you’ve ever tried to “fix” the problem yourself, you already know you can: 

❌ Tweak subject lines...

❌ Remove images...

❌ Ask subscribers to drag your emails to Primary...

❌ Clean your list...

❌ Change your ESP...

❌ Test endless templates… 

❌ And still end up spending hours trying to get an email out, without any guarantee it will even reach the inbox.

The problem is:

Gmail is constantly updating their algorithm, making it almost impossible to diagnose and fix deliverability issues on your own.

Even if you know your emails are going to Promotions or Spam, figuring out why (and how to fix it) feels almost impossible.

But what if there was a one-click software that could integrate with your existing ESP to…

✅ Tell you exactly where each of your emails is landing
✅ Fix Promotions Tab and Spam issues with a single click
✅ Boost opens, clicks, and sales - without switching platforms or guessing what to test next

Well, that’s exactly what we built.

It’s called EmailDeliverability.com/grow - the world’s only software that solves Promotions Tab and Spam problems with a single click.

✅ Works with every major ESP

✅ Boosts opens, clicks, and sales by 10 percentage points or more

Not only have we helped companies like BioTrust, SmartMarketer, Sam Ovens, 10X Advisor Network, and more…

But we’ve also helped our clients:

- Add 20.2% to their open rates in just 1 email

- Nearly double monthly email revenue without sending more campaigns

swipes.headline: Increase Email Revenue With 1 Click | Deliverability Software
swipes.primaryText:
Your email list isn’t dead.

Your copy isn’t the problem.

And your audience didn’t lose interest in your emails overnight.

For years, you’ve been told your email open rates and sales have dropped because of poor subject lines, weak copy, or lack of engagement.

But that’s not the real reason your emails stopped performing.

The reality is…

Your emails aren’t performing as well as they should because…

Gmail is just hiding them from your audience.

Here’s what’s really happening behind the scenes:

1️⃣ Gmail’s algorithm automatically filters most marketing emails into the Promotions Tab (or worse, Spam).

2️⃣ Once that happens, your subscribers never even see your messages because people rarely check those tabs.

3️⃣ Gmail then takes that low engagement as proof that your future emails “don’t belong in Primary.”

So your visibility keeps dropping…

Your open rates keep decreasing…

Your sales keep shrinking…

And you’re just there watching it all happen, wondering:

“What did I do wrong?”

“Was my copy not good enough?”

“Or is my email list really just… dead?”

But it’s not.

Your audience is still there, eagerly waiting to hear from you…

They just can’t see your emails.

So what can you do to fix it?

And how can you finally get your emails to consistently land in the primary inbox?

Well, you could try solving it the hard way……

Keep guessing, testing and wasting hours trying to diagnose a problem you can’t even see.

Or you can do it the easy way…

By simply installing the Email Deliverability Software.

Why are so many business owners struggling to generate sales from email, even though everyone says “the money is in the list”?

It’s not because email is dead…

It’s not that your subject lines need some work…

And it’s definitely not because your list has stopped caring.

The real reason why most businesses struggle to make sales from email is because the majority of the emails they send out never even make it to the Primary Inbox.

You see, due to Gmail’s constant algorithm updates, more and more emails are being filtered straight into the Promotions tab… or worse, the Spam folder.

Which means your subscribers never actually see them… and if they don’t see your emails, they can’t buy from you.

That’s why all the usual fixes don’t work:

❌ Tweaking subject lines

❌ Writing better copy

❌ Switching send times

❌ Cleaning your list over and over

❌ Even switching ESPs

None of that matters if your deliverability is broken.

So what’s the solution?

Up until now, there were only 2 options:

Keep guessing, testing, and wasting hours trying to “trick” Gmail’s filters

Hire expensive consultants with no guarantee they’ll actually solve the problem

Knowing this, we knew there had to be a better way.

A way that didn’t require extra time, endless guesswork, or thousands in consulting fees.

swipes.headline: Most coaches write one email and wonder why no one bites.⁠
swipes.primaryText:
Most coaches write one email and wonder why no one bites.⁠

We write five… and turn inboxes into income.⁠

Here’s the deal:⁠
One good idea = five banging emails.⁠

Same message. Different angles. Zero snooze.⁠

1️⃣ Problem – “This hurts. Wanna fix it?”⁠
2️⃣ Proof – “Meet Bob. He fixed it.”⁠
3️⃣ Philosophy – “Most people think X. They’re wrong. Here’s why.”⁠
4️⃣ Plan – “Here’s my 5-step path out.”⁠
5️⃣ Pitch – “I’m doing a thing. Wanna come?”⁠

That’s it.⁠

Five flavours. One message.⁠
Drip. Drip. Booked.⁠

If you want to turn your next idea into a campaign that actually converts—we should talk.

swipes.headline: Every coach ever: “Pick a niche.”⁠
swipes.primaryText:
Every coach ever: “Pick a niche.”⁠
⁠
Me: “Cool. But you’re doing it sideways.”⁠
⁠
Most coaches think niche means choosing a market—like gyms, or dentists, or underwater basket-weavers.⁠
⁠
But inside every market? There’s a vertical stack of humans.⁠
⁠
Bleeding. Sleeping. Stable. Leading.⁠
⁠
Pick the wrong level, and everything feels like a grind—slow sales, slower results, and too much effort for too little progress.⁠
⁠
Pick the right level? Sales click. Clients win faster. You charge more and deliver less (in the best way).⁠
⁠
📉 Pain vs 📈 Progress. That’s the real niche nobody talks about.⁠
⁠
Don’t go sideways. Go deep.⁠
⁠
Let me know in the comments what level your clients are at—Bleeding, Sleeping, Stable, or Leading.

swipes.headline: The Tiger Table
swipes.primaryText:
In this episode, we sit down with Dan Martell and Taki Moore to dismantle the old playbook of corporate marketing. They argue that we are living through a “silent crash” of trust, in which the era of the faceless corporation is ending, and the age of the founder-led media company has begun.

We explore why most business owners are still playing “amateur” by treating content as a lottery ticket rather than a compounding asset. Dan and Taki break down the philosophy behind building a media infrastructure that you actually own, rather than indefinitely renting attention from the algorithms.

We go deep on the psychology of influence: why “expertise” can sometimes be a liability, how to design creative workflows that scale beyond the founder, and the specific mental models required to turn a personal brand into a defensive moat for your business.

Life coach, business coach, health coach, sex coach, chat-gpt coach (coming soon 🙂)…

You are talking to a good prospect and when she ask you what you do you say:

A dime a dozen these days.

It works regardless what type of coach you are.

swipes.headline: How much would YOU pay for an umbrella?
swipes.primaryText:
How much would YOU pay for an umbrella? 

Most people pay around $10 to $20, $50 tops... 

Of course the price can vary depending on the brand, quality, and design of the umbrella.

But did you know that some high-end brands like Pasotti sell umbrellas for $300 to $800? 

Crazy, right?

Now, you might be wondering why someone would shell out hundreds of dollars for an umbrella when a $15 one could do the same job. 

The answer is simple: it's not just about keeping dry.

It’s about status. 

It’s about the future.

It’s about ego appeal.

People who invest in high-quality products tend to take better care of them, which means they last longer.

So, if you want to sell high-ticket products and services, it's not just about working harder or changing what you sell. 

It's about understanding your customer's desire and appealing to it. After all, people are willing to pay for the things they really value.

How can you apply this concept in your business?

swipes.headline: Unlock Your Dream Team
swipes.primaryText:
From solopreneur to leading a team of 70+ in just 5 years?

Meet Dev Gadhvi.

When Dev started his entrepreneurial journey, he was essentially running a one-man show.

Like many passionate coaches and consultants, he had the knowledge and drive to help people, but he was missing something crucial...

The ability to build and lead a high-performing team.

Dev was trapped in the classic entrepreneur's dilemma: working IN his business instead of ON his business.

Every client required his personal attention. Every strategy session meant his direct involvement. Every decision had to go through him.

He was the bottleneck in his own success.

But Dev knew there had to be a better way to scale without sacrificing quality or burning out.

That's when he discovered Dan's proven system for building dream teams.
Through Dan's mentorship, Dev learned how to identify the right people, hire with confidence, and create a team that could execute his vision without constant oversight.

The transformation was remarkable.

In just 5 years, Dev went from being a one-person operation to successfully leading a team of over 70 members.

His business evolved from a job he owned to a true enterprise that scales without him being involved in every decision.

In Dev's own words: "From a one-man show to 70+ team members in 5 years—thanks to Dan's mentorship."

This isn't just about adding employees. It's about building a team that thinks like owners, executes with precision, and frees you to focus on what you do best.

swipes.headline: How CEO Communicate Effectively
swipes.primaryText:
Your team is guessing.

Right now, as you read this, someone on your team is trying to figure out what you actually wanted when you gave them that task last week.

They're too scared to ask for clarification because they don't want to look stupid.

So they're just... guessing.

And next week, when they deliver something completely different from what you had in mind, you'll wonder why your team "can't execute."

Here's what most business owners don't realize...

If you're 100% clear in your head, your team is probably only 50% clear on what you actually want.

And if you're only 50% clear? They're operating at maybe 5% clarity.

That's why nothing gets done the way you envision it.

The problem isn't that your team can't execute. The problem is you don't know how to communicate as a CEO.

Most entrepreneurs can work one-on-one with 2-3 people just fine. But the minute they hit 7, 10, or 20 team members? They're completely lost.

They don't know how to mobilize competing priorities or talk to multiple people without everything falling through the cracks.

So they become the bottleneck. Everything has to go through them because they're the only one who "really gets it."

Here's the truth: Communication isn't just saying something. It's message sent, message received, and message acted upon.

Just because you said it doesn't mean they heard what you meant. And even if they heard it, that doesn't mean they know how to act on it.

In this video, I break down the exact communication framework that allows you to scale from 3 people to 50+ without losing your mind.

This is the same system that prevents your team from guessing and gets them executing at the level you're thinking.

If you're tired of being the translation department for your own ideas, watch this now.

swipes.headline: Powerful lessons E-myth
swipes.primaryText:
Are you running a business?

Or do you have an expensive job you can't quit?

Most business owners think they're running a business, but they're not.

If they can't take a 2-week vacation without everything falling apart...

If every decision has to go through them...

If their business stops making money the moment they stop working...

Then they don't own a business.

They own a job. A very demanding, stressful job that they can never leave.

Here's the brutal truth most business owners don't want to hear...

They're not actually business owners at all.

They're just technicians who had what Michael Gerber calls an "entrepreneurial seizure."

You know the story...

They're good at what they do. Really good.

One day they think: "I could do this better than my boss. I should start my own business."

So they do.

But here's the problem...

Being good at the technical work and knowing how to 

BUILD a business are two completely different skill sets.
It's like knowing how to drive a car vs. knowing how to build one.

Just because they can do the job doesn't mean they know how to create a business that works WITHOUT them.

So how do you fix this?

How do you build a business that actually works without you being there 24/7?

In this video, I break down the 5 game-changing lessons from Michael Gerber's "E-Myth" that completely transformed how I think about business.

These aren't just theory. I've actually met Michael personally several times, and I've applied these principles to build multiple 7-figure businesses.

If you're tired of being a slave to your own business, watch this now.

swipes.headline: How CEO Communicate Effectively
swipes.primaryText:
"We need to have a meeting about this."

How many times have you heard that phrase this week?

And how many of those meetings actually solved anything?

Most business owners are meeting addicts without even realizing it.

Someone has a question? Let's have a meeting.

There's a problem? Let's have a meeting.

Need to make a decision? You guessed it... meeting time.

But here's what's really happening...

Their teams are spending more time talking ABOUT the work than actually DOING the work.

They're scheduling meetings to plan other meetings.

They're having 2-hour discussions that could have been resolved with a 5-minute conversation.

And the worst part? Most of these meetings end exactly where they started - with no clear decisions, no action items, and everyone more confused than before.

So why do business owners keep falling into this trap?

Because nobody ever taught them how to run an effective meeting.

In this video, I break down the 7 strategies we use to make our meetings so valuable that people actually look forward to them.

These aren't theory - they're the exact systems we've developed after years of testing what works and what doesn't.

If you want to stop wasting hours in pointless meetings and start using them to drive real results, watch this now.

swipes.headline: Communication Secrets for Teams
swipes.primaryText:
I used to be the CEO my team secretly hated.

Every time I came back from an event or finished a business book, I'd dump 20 new ideas on them and expect everything implemented in 10 days.

My team called it "catching bombs" - and they were in chaos for months at a time.

Sound familiar?

Last month, I hosted a private dinner for my Dragon 100 members in Europe, and I discovered something shocking...

These high-level business owners were making the exact same mistake I used to make.

They were "dropping bombs" on their teams.

Coming back from events with a hundred new strategies, dumping them all on their team with no context, no priorities, and no clear deadlines.

The result? Complete chaos.

Their teams would spend months scrambling to figure out what actually mattered while nothing got done properly.

Here's what I realized during that conversation...

The problem isn't that their team can't execute. The problem is they don't know HOW to give clear direction.

During this dinner, I shared the exact communication framework that transformed how my team operates - the same system that saved me from being the "bomb-dropping" CEO.

It's simple, but it's not easy.

And when you get it right, your team goes from confused and overwhelmed to laser-focused and unstoppable.

In this clip from that private dinner, you'll hear the behind-the-scenes strategies I normally only share with my highest-level clients.

If you're tired of your great ideas dying in execution hell, watch this now.

swipes.headline: Dan Lok
swipes.primaryText:
Everyone says your first hire should be a virtual assistant.
They're wrong.

Sure, a VA will save you some time with admin tasks and scheduling.

But they won't solve your real problem.

You know what your real problem is?

You're stuck on sales calls all day with people who can't afford you.

Tire kickers who just want free advice.

Prospects who waste 45 minutes of your time before revealing they have a $500 budget for something that costs $5,000.

Meanwhile, your actual paying clients aren't getting the attention they deserve because you're too busy giving away free strategy sessions to people who will never buy.

Here's what successful coaches and consultants figured out...

There's one specific role that transforms everything.

This one hire stops you from wasting time with unqualified prospects, dramatically increases your close rate, and frees up your calendar to focus on paying clients.

It's not what most people think.

And it's probably not what you think either.

In this video, I reveal exactly what this role is, why it should be your next hire, and how to structure it so you never waste time on unqualified prospects again.

If you're tired of running a charity instead of a business, watch this now.

swipes.headline: What’s the difference between a $100,000 watch vs. a $100 watch?
swipes.primaryText:
What’s the difference between a $100,000 watch vs. a $100 watch?

Both watches tell time.

But people who buy a six figure Patek Philippe watch, don’t buy it because it can tell the time better than a regular $100 watch.

It’s not because of the value.

It’s not because of the brand

It’s not even to show off.

These Patek Phillippe’s evil geniuses have come up with something else that helps them have a triple digit margin% on their products.

Watch this video to discover how you can apply the same concept to sell high ticket coaching products and services in your business.

swipes.headline: 100 Foods Before 1? That’s Not the Point.

The idea is that more diversity + more flavors and more practice with texture = diverse palette and adventurous eating!

Let’s set up digestion, and develop baby’s microbiome so they can really digest plants! (All of our plant digestion happens by the microbes in our lower intestines) 🌿

Focus on local foods, organic foods, well-cooked foods.

I know babies who are absolutely thriving on 5 foods. And still need it to be that way. (for now)

I know babies who stay on lamb meat stock for months.

I know babies who have reversed cut and bleeding eczema symptoms from soft cooked collagenous parts ONLY!

I also know babies who eat a large variety of local, seasonal and ancestral foods starting with & prioritizing gut building foods!

🍖There’s no “one way” to do solids, but there are tried and true methods of serving and preparing foods that humans have been relying on for a long time. We need more of that for our babies!

swipes.headline: I’m Greg Lutzka, and I started 'Skate Life' to unite skaters serious about tricks, finding new spots, and skate culture—all free.
swipes.primaryText:
I’m Greg Lutzka, and I started 'Skate Life' to unite skaters serious about tricks, finding new spots, and skate culture—all free.

I had to figure out skateboarding alone. Connecting with other skaters who get it was impossible outside my local scene.

For years, I hit parks and new spots solo, believing a real skating community was hard to find unless you were already “in.”

Landing tricks is one aspect. The real skate lifestyle is about having a crew who understands the culture and is motivated to push boundaries. 

But that side of skating felt exclusive.

I built what is missing. 

Skate Life is a place where skaters celebrate every trick, spot, and style. You’ll find skaters worldwide who live for skating just like you.

Every month, we host challenges where members showcase their best tricks, compete, and win prizes. 

We run live Q&A sessions with myself and other top skaters, where you can get direct answers and advice.

Our in-person meetups happen at private skateparks, creating exceptional sessions that feature live music, competitions, and prizes. 

We discuss what it takes to get noticed, connect with sponsors, and succeed in the industry.

YES, it’s all free!

We keep it rooted in skate culture. Our members share local spots, post their best tricks, and explore the history that shapes skateboarding today.

Skate Life is about skating with purpose, pushing limits, and finding your crew. Join now and let’s create something genuine.

If you want to deepen your skateboarding journey, Skate Life is here for you. Join us if you’re ready to go beyond tricks and competitions and explore the real culture of skating.

Join Free
https://www.skool.com/skate/about

—Greg Lutzka

swipes.headline: Fitness Business Mentors
swipes.primaryText:
By now, you’re not trying to be convinced.
You’re trying to be sure.

You’ve already done the thinking most people avoid.

You’ve admitted Instagram brings clients you don’t want.
You’ve accepted that more effort isn’t the answer.
You’ve recognized that environment shapes buyer quality.

So this isn’t about whether LinkedIn works.

It’s about whether this approach fits the kind of business you’re building.

At this stage, you’re not interested in experiments, trends, or “try this and see” strategies. You’re interested in leverage.

You want to know whether this attracts people who decide quickly.
Whether it reduces emotional labor instead of adding to it.
Whether it lets you charge more without constantly justifying it.

And just as importantly, whether it forces you to become someone you don’t want to be.

That last part matters more than most people admit.

You didn’t build your business to become louder.
You didn’t build it to perform for attention.
You didn’t build it to chase.

You built it because you’re competent, and competence should compound.

Most marketing systems fall apart at this stage for one reason. They optimize for volume instead of fit.

They assume everyone wants more leads.
They assume more conversations are better.
They assume scale means exposure.

You already know better.

You don’t want more calls, more DMs, or more explaining.
You want cleaner conversations.

Conversations that start with:
“I read what you wrote.”
“This made sense to me.”
“I think we should talk.”

That only happens when your thinking is visible, your positioning is clear, and your authority is placed intentionally.

This is where most coaches get tripped up.

They hear “LinkedIn plus content plus ads” and imagine posting daily, becoming corporate, or running ads that feel salesy.

That’s not what this is.

This is about placement, not performance.

It’s about putting the right ideas in front of the right people consistently so the wrong people never raise their hand in the first place.

That’s why this only works for a specific kind of coach.

It works if you already have results.
If you already charge premium prices.
If you already know who you don’t want to work with.

It does not work if you’re new, need validation, or want fast dopamine from likes and comments.

LinkedIn doesn’t reward enthusiasm. It rewards judgment. And judgment only lands when it’s grounded in experience.

This approach assumes you can articulate how high performers think, understand tradeoffs instead of just tactics, and explain fitness as a performance asset rather than a vanity goal.

If that excites you, this fits.
If it intimidates you, it doesn’t.

There’s something else worth saying plainly.

This isn’t about abandoning Instagram.
It’s about no longer depending on it.

Instagram stays where it works best: visibility, social proof, light touchpoints.
It just stops being the engine.

LinkedIn becomes where decisions are made, authority is built, and premium demand originates.

That separation alone changes how your business feels.

You stop dreading leads.
You stop bracing for conversations.
You stop negotiating your value.

The people who reach out already see you as a peer, not a personality.

Prices rise naturally. Not because you forced them, but because the room changed.

This is the difference between a business that scales with effort and one that scales with positioning.

One always feels busy.
The other feels calm.

If you’re still reading, you’re past curiosity. You’re evaluating standards.

This is for online fitness coaches doing $12K to $25K a month who want fewer, better clients, higher prices without resistance, authority that compounds, and a business that doesn’t depend on daily output.

It’s not for beginners, influencers, or anyone chasing hype, hacks, or shortcuts.

That’s intentional.

The goal isn’t to help everyone grow.
It’s to help the right people grow without sacrificing their standards.

If that aligns, you already know what to do.

See how this works.

swipes.headline: Fitness Business Mentors
swipes.primaryText:
Once you realize Instagram isn’t broken, it’s just doing exactly what it was designed to do, a new question takes over.

Not: “How do I post better?”
But: “Where do the kinds of clients I actually want spend their time?”

This is the turning point for most online fitness coaches who are doing real money but feel capped. They finally stop trying to force Instagram to behave like something it’s not.

Because Instagram is a consumer platform. It’s built for browsing, relating, consuming, and delaying. Which means it naturally attracts people who want to feel ready before they decide.

That’s fine early on.

But once you want higher prices, fewer clients, faster decisions, and less emotional labor, you start needing a different kind of room. A room where people already make decisions for a living.

This is where the conversation shifts from content strategy to environment. Because environment shapes behavior. Put the same offer in two different places and you’ll get two completely different types of buyers. Not because the offer changed. Because the context did.

High-level clients, business owners, executives, decision-makers, don’t look for solutions the same way consumers do. They don’t scroll hoping to feel inspired. They don’t need motivation. They don’t want entertainment.

They want clarity.

They want to read, evaluate, recognize expertise quickly, and move on.

That’s why they naturally gravitate toward environments built around professional identity. Places where long-form thinking is normal, credentials matter, authority is respected, and decisions are expected.

This is where LinkedIn quietly outperforms every other platform for high-end clients. Not because it’s trendy or new, but because of why people are there.

People don’t open LinkedIn to kill time. They open it to learn, evaluate, decide, and hire. They’re already in a business mindset.

So when fitness expertise shows up in that context, it lands differently. It’s no longer “Here’s how to get in shape.” It becomes “Here’s how high performers protect energy, longevity, and execution.”

That subtle shift changes everything. Because decision-makers don’t buy fitness. They buy performance continuity. They buy the ability to show up sharper, think clearer, and lead longer.

When your message is placed inside a professional environment, you stop competing with influencers, trends, and noise. You start competing with consultants, advisors, and experts.

That’s a very different playing field.

This is also why long-form content matters so much more here. A 1,000-word article that explains how you think will outperform 100 short posts when it comes to client quality. Not in likes or comments, but in the tone of the conversations it creates.

People who reach out after reading long-form authority don’t ask “How much is it?” They ask “What does working together look like?” or “Are you taking on clients right now?” Because they’ve already decided you’re competent. They’re just checking for fit.

This is the moment many online fitness coaches feel something unexpected: relief.

For the first time, growth doesn’t feel like louder posting, more DMs, or more filtering. It feels like placement. Putting your thinking in front of people who already value thinking.

And once you experience even one or two conversations that feel clean, with no convincing, no explaining, and no emotional labor, it’s hard to go back.

You realize this is what was missing. Not a better script. Not tighter boundaries. A better environment.

Instagram didn’t fail you. It just isn’t where elite clients decide.

LinkedIn isn’t magic. It’s simply where decisions already happen.

And when you understand that, marketing stops feeling like something you have to push. It starts feeling like something you place.

That’s the lever that replaces effort at this stage. Not hacks. Not hustle. Not hype.

Authority, in the right room.

If you want to see how this works in practice, tap Learn More.

swipes.headline: Fitness Business Mentors
swipes.primaryText:
There’s a moment that hits a lot of successful online fitness coaches, usually somewhere between $12,000 and $25,000 a month, where growth stops feeling exciting.

Not because you don’t want more money.
Not because you don’t believe you’re capable.

But because you’ve started to associate growth with something you secretly dread.

More leads.
More conversations.
More people.

And if you’re honest, more of the wrong people.

You don’t say this out loud, because it sounds harsh.
And because you know how many coaches would kill to be where you are.

But internally, there’s a quiet resistance every time you think about turning things up.

Because you know exactly what happens when you do.

Your Instagram DMs fill up.

Not with decisive, ready to go clients, but with people who:

Ask questions you’ve already answered publicly

Love your content but can’t afford your program

Need reassurance, motivation, and endless context

Want options, payment plans, and exceptions

You don’t hate these people as humans.

But you hate what working with too many of them does to your business, and to you.

It turns sales into emotional labor.
It makes growth feel heavy instead of clean.
And it quietly teaches you that more marketing equals more headaches.

So you do something most people don’t notice from the outside.

You hold back.

You post, but not as aggressively as you could.
You stay consistent, but not all in.
You hesitate before scaling, not because you’re lazy, but because you don’t want to invite chaos.

That’s the part no one talks about.

You’re not avoiding growth.
You’re avoiding the clients growth has brought you so far.

Instagram worked when you were building momentum.

It helped you get visible.
It helped you prove demand.

But now it feels like a machine that keeps sending you people who consume instead of decide.

And that creates a very specific internal conflict.

On one hand, you want:

Fewer clients

Higher prices

People who respect your time

People who don’t need convincing

On the other hand, you’re painfully aware that pushing harder on Instagram just gives you more of what you already don’t want.

So even though your business works, it doesn’t feel aligned.

Marketing feels like a tax.
DMs feel like a chore.
And scaling feels like signing up for more future frustration.

You don’t hate coaching.

You hate the idea that growth means lowering your standards.

And that’s the moment where something important is happening, even if you haven’t put words to it yet.

You’re realizing that not all growth channels attract the same kind of people.

Some environments attract:

Browsers

Consumers

People looking for inspiration

Other environments attract:

Decision makers

Buyers

People who already value expertise

The problem isn’t that your offer isn’t premium enough.

It’s that the room you’re standing in isn’t filled with premium buyers.

Instagram is built for attention.
It rewards relatability, frequency, and emotion.

And while that’s powerful early on, it also shapes who raises their hand.

It’s not surprising that a platform built for scrolling sends you people who scroll.

What is surprising is how many experienced coaches blame themselves for this instead of questioning the environment.

They assume:

I need better boundaries

I need better scripts

I just need to filter harder

But none of those change the fundamental issue.

The platform decides who shows up before you ever speak.

This is why some coaches quietly start wondering about alternatives, not out of curiosity, but out of necessity.

They don’t want more eyeballs.
They want better rooms.

Places where:

Long form thinking is normal

Professional identity matters

People make decisions for a living

They haven’t fully connected the dots yet.

They just know this much.

If growth means more Instagram leads, they’re not sure they want to grow that way.

And if that thought feels familiar, the mix of ambition and disgust, you’re not broken.

You’re just further along than most people admit.

Tap Learn More to see why some platforms naturally attract better clients, and others don’t.

swipes.headline: Stop Chasing Instagram Likes for Big Deals
swipes.primaryText:
This moment usually comes after years in the game.
Once the problem is clear, the search begins.

You start paying attention to positioning. Content. Authority. Platforms. You know something needs to change upstream.

But almost every solution you encounter feels misaligned.

Too loud.
Too frequent.
Too performative.

Most visibility strategies are designed for people trying to establish credibility. They assume you need to prove something.

You do not.

You need to translate something.

Years of experience.
Pattern recognition.
Judgment.

The problem is not that you do not know what to say. It is that you refuse to say it badly.

You are not interested in becoming a content machine. You are interested in being understood.

You want the right people to recognize you quickly. Not everyone to see you.

That distinction matters.

Attention attracts everyone.

Authority attracts decision makers.

Most systems chase the first.

You need the second.

This is where the idea of a different approach begins to take shape.

One that prioritizes depth over frequency.
Clarity over volume.
Signal over noise.

A system that does not ask you to perform, exaggerate, or simplify your thinking.

A system that respects who you are and who you serve.

If that exists, it would not feel like marketing. It would feel like alignment.

See how this works.

swipes.headline: Fitness Business Mentors
swipes.primaryText:
By this point, something has clicked.

You’re no longer wondering whether Instagram is sending the wrong clients. You’re no longer questioning whether decision-makers exist outside of it. You know they do.

The real question now is quieter and more dangerous:

What if LinkedIn could work for me, but I mess it up?

Because LinkedIn has a reputation. Corporate. Cringe. Spammy. Full of people shouting advice they don’t follow. And the last thing you want is to trade Instagram DMs for cold messages that make you feel like a desperate salesperson in a blazer.

So you hesitate.

Not because you doubt the platform, but because you don’t trust the execution.

That hesitation is justified.

Most online fitness coaches who try LinkedIn fail for one simple reason. They bring Instagram behavior into a professional environment.

They post short, vague motivation. They talk about discipline without context. They chase engagement instead of credibility.

When it doesn’t work, they conclude: “LinkedIn doesn’t work for fitness.”

But that’s like walking into a boardroom and yelling like you’re on a stage. The room isn’t wrong. The behavior is.

LinkedIn doesn’t reward charisma. It rewards clarity. It doesn’t reward frequency. It rewards thoughtfulness. And it absolutely does not reward trying to hack attention.

What it rewards is this: can you clearly articulate a problem that high performers already know they have, and explain it in a way that makes them trust your judgment?

That’s it.

The mistake most fitness coaches make is assuming LinkedIn is about being professional. It’s not. It’s about being precise.

Decision-makers don’t want inspiration. They want to recognize competence quickly.

That’s why long-form content works so well here. Not blogs for SEO. Not motivational essays. Clear, grounded explanations that show how you think, how you diagnose problems, and how you make decisions.

When a business owner reads something and thinks, “This person understands pressure, tradeoffs, and execution,” they don’t ask for proof. They assume it.

This is also why paid ads on LinkedIn work very differently than anywhere else. They’re not meant to convert the way Instagram ads do. They’re meant to place authority at scale. Quietly putting the right thinking in front of the right people, without noise, without chasing, without DM gymnastics.

Done correctly, LinkedIn doesn’t feel like marketing. It feels like being visible in the right rooms, having fewer and better conversations, and letting people self-select before they ever reach out.

This is the part most coaches miss.

They think LinkedIn is about posting more, messaging more, hustling harder. In reality, it’s about doing less, but doing it in the right order.

Positioning first. You don’t talk about fitness. You talk about performance, longevity, and decision fatigue.

Long-form authority second. One clear article can outperform months of short posts.

Paid amplification third. Not to sell, but to consistently place your thinking in front of decision-makers.

When this is done right, something subtle happens.

The tone of inbound changes.

People don’t say, “Hey, how much is it?”
They say, “I read your article.”
“I agree with how you framed that.”
“I think we should talk.”

That’s the tell.

Because you’re no longer convincing. You’re being recognized.

This is what most experienced online fitness coaches are actually searching for, even if they don’t say it out loud. Not more leads. Not more attention. Fewer conversations that start further down the decision path.

That’s why LinkedIn works when you know what you’re doing.

It’s also why trying to figure it out yourself usually leads to frustration. Not because it’s complex, but because the margin for error is higher. Instagram lets you be sloppy. LinkedIn does not.

The coaches who succeed here don’t experiment casually. They treat it like positioning, because that’s what it is.

They stop asking, “How do I get more leads?”
And start asking, “How do I show up like someone worth deciding on?”

Once you see that distinction, the platform stops feeling intimidating. It feels obvious.

The only remaining question becomes: is there a way to do this correctly without wasting months guessing?

That’s when you’re ready for the final step.

See how this works.

swipes.headline: Why referral-based growth quietly caps experienced fitness businesses
swipes.primaryText:
At some point, the discomfort sharpens.

It stops feeling vague and starts feeling directional.

You realize the issue is not that you cannot grow. It is that growth depends too much on things you do not control.

Referrals.
Timing.
Visibility spikes you did not design.

You have enough experience now to know that unpredictability is the real tax. Not income dips. Not hard weeks. Uncertainty.

You start asking different questions.

Why does demand feel episodic instead of steady?
Why does momentum feel borrowed instead of owned?
Why do good months rely on people talking about me instead of finding me?

This is where the problem reveals itself.

Your business still runs on proximity.

Who knows you.
Who remembers you.
Who happens to mention your name when someone asks.

Proximity built your foundation. It does not scale your future.

Because proximity does not compound.

Authority does.

You are not lacking credibility. You are lacking a system that makes that credibility visible without your constant involvement.

This realization is uncomfortable because it reframes your success.

You did not build something fragile.

 You built something under-positioned.

The market has changed around you. Buyers now assume expertise is visible. If someone is good, they expect to see evidence before the conversation ever starts.

Not testimonials. Perspective.

How you think.
What you notice.
What you disagree with.

Without that signal, even high-level buyers default to what they can see.

And what they can see is often not the best. It is the loudest.

This is where resistance shows up.

Because every obvious path to visibility feels wrong.

The platforms feel noisy.
The content feels performative.
The advice feels built for beginners trying to look credible.

You are credible. You just are not positioned.

The problem is no longer mysterious.

It is structural.

You are operating a high-level business with a low-leverage acquisition model.

Until that changes, growth will always feel slightly out of your hands.

See how this works.

swipes.headline: Fitness Business Mentors
swipes.primaryText:
By the time you’re doing somewhere between $12,000 and $25,000 a month as an online fitness coach, you’ve already answered the hardest question.

This works.

You know how to coach.
You know how to sell.
You know how to get people results.

So when the business still feels heavier than it should, the frustration hits differently.

This isn’t beginner confusion.
It isn’t lack of confidence.
It isn’t laziness.

It’s more specific than that.

You’ve started to notice that the part of your business you dislike most isn’t coaching.
It’s who marketing brings you.

Instagram, in particular.

You’ve played the game. You’ve posted, shown up, educated, stayed consistent. And yes, it’s brought you clients. But it’s also brought a pattern you can’t ignore anymore.

People who take forever to decide.
People who ask questions that signal they haven’t really listened.
People who need reassurance before committing.
People who want to “think about it” after saying they’re ready.
People who love your content but don’t value your time.

Individually, none of this is outrageous.

Stacked together, day after day, it changes how growth feels.

Because you start to realize something uncomfortable. More Instagram exposure doesn’t feel like progress. It feels like signing up for more emotional labor.

That’s when resistance creeps in.

Not resistance to success. Resistance to what success currently looks like.

You don’t stop marketing entirely. But you stop pushing. You hesitate before turning ads back on. You delay the next launch. You tell yourself you’ll “dial things in” first.

From the outside, it looks like patience.
From the inside, it’s avoidance.

Because you already know the tradeoff.

More reach on Instagram means more explaining, more filtering, more managing, more of the same type of client.

So even though you want higher prices, fewer clients, better conversations, and cleaner sales, you subconsciously associate growth with more frustration.

That’s the part no one says out loud.

You don’t hate marketing.
You hate what your current marketing environment keeps producing.

At this stage, most coaches blame themselves.

They assume they need stronger boundaries, better scripts, or tighter filtering.

None of that changes the core issue.

Because the problem isn’t how you handle leads. It’s where those leads come from.

Instagram is not a neutral environment.

It’s designed for browsing, consuming, reacting, and relating. It rewards frequency, personality, emotion, and accessibility.

That isn’t inherently bad. It’s exactly why it works early on.

But those same design choices shape who feels comfortable raising their hand.

People who scroll all day tend to delay decisions, seek validation, need more context, and look for inspiration before action.

That’s not a character flaw. It’s a behavior pattern shaped by the environment.

What becomes a problem is staying in that environment after your business outgrows it.

At a certain level, filtering harder doesn’t fix source quality.

You can raise prices, add applications, tighten messaging, and still feel the same tone in the conversations. Because the platform already pre-qualifies the mindset of the people reaching out.

This is why some online fitness coaches quietly start feeling resentful.

Not toward their audience as people, but toward the situation.

They feel like they’ve outgrown the room they’re standing in.

Once that thought enters your head, it’s hard to ignore.

You start noticing other coaches. Not the loud ones. Not the ones dancing on Reels. The quieter ones.

They post less.
They sell without urgency.
They work with fewer clients.
They charge more without pushback.

They don’t seem busier. They don’t seem stressed. They don’t seem like they’re convincing anyone.

They seem selective.

That’s usually when the real question forms.

What if it’s not about marketing harder.
What if it’s about marketing in a different environment.

An environment where long-form thinking is normal.
Where professional identity matters.
Where people make decisions for a living.
Where authority carries weight.

Places where people don’t ask, “Can I afford this?”
They ask, “What does working together look like?”

This isn’t about abandoning Instagram or declaring it bad. It’s about recognizing that platforms produce behavior.

And the behavior Instagram produces doesn’t match the business you want to build next.

You don’t want more followers.
You want fewer, better conversations.

You don’t want more leads.
You want fewer, decisive ones.

And you don’t want to grow at the cost of your standards.

If this tension feels familiar, the mix of ambition and quiet disgust, it doesn’t mean you’re difficult.

It means you’re ready for a different room.

You just haven’t fully seen why yet.

See how this works.

You're basing your opinion on an algorithm that doesn't even exist anymore.
